I'm just thinking about when Tom arrived in Mongi. And now look at you. [93]To the manner born. [94]Very. [95]Where's Mr MacCarron? [96]I just don't believe that! [97]Such as? I have to tell Mr Greenleaf. [107]He promised me. I swear I'll never take off this ring until the day - [108]I was looking for a needle and thread. I wasn't snooping. dialogues.PETER: [1]Peter Smith-Kingsley. I've heard about you, of course - from Marge, and Dickie. [2]Where are you hiding him? He's impossible, isn't he? [3]Yes, what happened? I heard you were desperate to come. I was looking forward to rowing you around. [4]Well hurry, before we sink. Should I give you my telephone number in Venice? [5]Look there's Meredith thingy - who's that, Marge? - they're in textiles... Meredith - God, how awful, I've spent Christmas in her house...! [6]Will we see you later? [7]And tomorrow? Tom Ripley. [14]Not at all. Morning Tom. [15]We think he's had a change of heart. So we should be celebrating. [16]That was moving, wasn't it? When Meredith said - Meredith's the American girl I saw last night, I know her, at the Opera, she's been seeing something of Dickie - [17]But the point is Dickie - well we know this - Dickie loves Marge and he misses her and apparently he's come to his senses... [31]Are you a homosexual? Interesting non-sequitur. [32]No. By the way, officially there are no Italian homosexuals. Makes Leonardo, Michelangelo very inconvenient. [33]Il signor Ripley ha una fidanzata, il signor Dickie ha una fidanzata e probabilmente il signor Freddie Miles ha molte fidanzate. [34]He says so many fiancÈes. [35]He wants to know if you killed Freddie Miles and then killed Dickie Greenleaf? [36]He's already angry, I don't think - [37]A ragione. A ragione. (You're right. You're right.) [42]That's the music talking. Harder to be bleak if you're playing Knees up Mother Brown. [43]No key, huh? [44]I think we sort of found each other. [45]Where's Dickie's father? [46]No, it's Tom's. Come back though. Come back. You know, you look so relaxed, like a completely different person. [62]How was it? [63]Was that Meredith? [64]Meredith Logue. You were kissing somebody. Looked like Meredith. [65]Didn't look that way - you know - from a distance. [66]Why lie? [67]Or Tom and Peter even. [68]Really, why? Sorry, I'm completely lost. Tom has secrets he doesn't want to tell me, and I wish he would. Tom has nightmares. That's not a good thing. Tom has someone to love him. That is a good thing! Tom is crushing me. Tom is crushing me. Tom, you're crushing me!
dialogues.MEREDITH:
[1]What's your secret? 
[2]No, it's just - you are American, aren't you? - no, I just, I have so much luggage, and you're so, uh, streamlined. It's humiliating. 
[3]I'm Meredith, by the way. Meredith Randall. 
[4]Hello. 
[5]You're not the Shipping Greenleaf's? 
[6]So now, did they put your suitcase in the wrong pile? It's just - upstairs - weren't you under the R stand? I thought I saw you there. 
[7]Which is? 
[8]The funny thing is, I'm not Randall either. I'm Logue. 
[9]As in the Textile Logues. Trying to shrug off the dress. I travel under my mother's name, too. 
[10]Right. 
[11]So - partners in disguise. Bye. 
[12]Dickie! Oh my God!  Ciao. 
[13]But you're going skiing with us Yankees, aren't you? 
[14]At Christmas. To Cortina with Freddie Miles and - 
[15]Everybody knows Freddie Miles. 
[16]Now? I don't think so. But I've met him, of course, and we've chatted and I know about you and Marge and Mongi and what an unreliable rat you are. Freddie said you were a rat and I thought to myself now I know why he travels under R. 
[17]Sorry, I wouldn't have made a joke if - 
[18]The truth is if you've had money your entire life, even if you despise it, which we do - agreed? - you're only truly comfortable around other people who have it and despise it. 
[19]I've never admitted that to anyone. 
[20]Show me the other one again. I like them both. 
[21]I know you're a jazz fiend but do you absolutely hate the Opera?  I've been trying to give my tickets away, it's tomorrow, but if you were prepared to be dragged... 
[22]I thought you were enjoying yourself? 
[23]You're crazy! It's freezing out there. 
[24]Okay then, you're crazy. 
[25]Don't worry. Really. Don't worry. 
[26]No, I absolutely understand. Of course. 
[27]Beating you away. 
[28]Will you meet me tomorrow?  Just to say goodbye in the daylight, properly? So it's not just this, it's too...you should always save pain for daylight... 
[29]I don't - is that by the Spanish Steps? 
[30]Peter? Hello, it's Meredith Logue. 
[31]I won't actually, although I think this might - are you waiting for Dickie? 
[32]You were at the Opera? Well, that explains - yes I was there. I was there with Dickie. 
[33]Marge, I don't know you, so I have no right, but Dickie loves you.  He's - I think you'll find he's coming home to you. 
[34]He told me everything. I was supposed to meet him fifteen minutes ago, so I...I'm going to go now, I think. Unless he meant us to meet - which would be a little cruel, wouldn't it? 
[35]Ripley? No. I heard about him, of course, but no, I didn't meet him. 
[36]Not for me. No, grazie. 
[37]I hope I didn't complicate matters, but nothing, nothing untoward happened, nothing to prevent you from welcoming him back, from marrying him...Goodbye. Goodbye Peter, please don't get up. 
[38]Dickie?  Dickie? 
[39]Dickie, my God! 
[40]I was looking at you, your clothes, I wouldn't have known you... 
[41]What? 
[42]Hardly. I couldn't be less alone. 
[43]And co. A lot of co. Oh, God, I've thought about you so much. 
[44]When I thought about you I was mostly hating you. Where've you been hiding? 
[45]You're kidding. 
[46]You know, the whole world thinks you killed Freddie? It's terrible. 
[47]So - are you travelling under R? 
[48]Dickie, are you with Peter Smith- Kingsley?  I bet you are. My aunt thought she saw him.

dialogues.ROVERINI: [1]Dickie Greenleaf? [2]Inspector Roverini. Can we come in? [3]It's a terrible shock, eh? What time did Signor Miles leave yesterday? We've had many requests and, of course, we say no - even to your fiancÈe. [11]Even your fiancÈe...? [12]What about Thomas Ripley? [13]You and Signor Ripley went to San Remo, is that right? dialogues.HERBERT GREENLEAF: [1]Most enjoyable. Herbert Greenleaf. [2]I see you were at Princeton. Then you'll most likely know our son, Dick. Dickie Greenleaf... [3]Yes. [4]Of course, Dickie's idea of music is Jazz. He has a saxophone. To my ear Jazz is just noise, just an insolent noise. [5]Yes. An exceptional young man. [6]Mongibello. Tiny place. South of Naples. Marge, his uh, the young lade is supposedly writing some kind of book. God knows what he does. By all accounts they spend the whole time on the beach. Or his sailboat. That's my son's talent, spending his allowance. [7]Could you ever conceive of going to Italy, Tom, persuade my son to come home? I'd pay you. I'd pay you 1000 dollars. [8]Good. Now you can go for a reason. [9]Tom. How are you? You look well. [10]Far cry from New York. [11]Marge, good morning. Unusual weather. [12]Pretty good. Sticking with hot water. [13]San Remo. The police are amateurs. Well, my boy, it's come to a pretty pass, hasn't it? [14]He's being thorough, that's all. I'm learning about my son, Tom, now he's missing. I'd like to talk to Tom alone - perhaps this afternoon? Would you mind? I've thought about going to the police but I can't face it. I can't face anything anymore. [21]Well, if we all pushed him away what about him pushing us away? You've been a great friend to my son. Everything is someone else's fault. We all want to sow wild oars. Somebody's got to - what's the word? The moment someone confronts him he lashes out. He lashes out. You know, people always say you can't choose your parents, but you can't choose your children. [22]Marge, there's female intuition, and then there are facts - [23]Tom. [24]Marge has been telling us about the rings. [25]Perhaps you didn't mention them because there's only one conclusion to be drawn. [26]I'm going to take Marge for a little walk, Tom. Mr MacCarron wants to talk with you. [27]No, he should talk to you alone.

dialogues.MACCARRON:
[1]Mr Ripley? I'm Alvin MacCarron. 
[2]I don't care for B.S. I don't care to hear it. I don't care to speak it. 
[3]Why do you think Dickie's father sent him to Europe in the first place? Did you know at Princeton Dickie Greenleaf half- killed a boy? 
[4]At a party. Over some girl. He kicked the kid several times in the head. Put him in the hospital. The boy had a wire fixed in his jaw. The Rome Police didn't think to ask Mr Greenleaf. 
[5]Nor did they think to check whether a Thomas Ripley had ever been a student at Princeton University. I turned up a Tom Ripley who'd been a piano tuner in the music department. 
[6]See - in America we're taught to check a fact before it becomes a fact. We're taught to nose around when a girl drowns herself, find out if that girl was pregnant, find out if Dickie had an embarrassment there. 
[7]Mr Greenleaf appreciates your loyalty. He really does. Marge, she's got a hundred theories, but there are a few things she doesn't know. We hope she never knows. 
[8]Three different people saw Dickie get into Freddie Miles' car. A man who won't identify himself because he was jumping someone else's wife at the time saw Dickie removing license plates from a red sports car. The Police know about this man because he happens to be a Policeman. 
[9]I found these in the basement of Dickie's apartment. They belonged to Freddie's car. Mr Greenleaf has asked me to lose them in the canal this evening. 
[10]Mr Greenleaf also feels there was a silent promise in Dickie's letter to you which he intends to honor. He intends to transfer a good part of Dickie's income from his trust into your name. He doesn't intend to give the Italian police any information about Dickie's past. He's rather hoping you'll feel the same.
